Description: Fragmentary rose granite standing figure of Mersuankh, the upper body now missing. The lower legs show that the figure originally adopted a striding pose, with the left leg advancing forward ahead of the right. The legs and feet are broad in size. Beside the left foot on top of the statue base is a brief crudely carved inscription. On the reverse is the lower portion of a wide back-pillar, which does not appear to be inscribed. There are chips to the stone surface around the left side of the base, and the reverse is also damaged across both corners of the base.
Curator's comments: This 5th Dynasty individual is associated with a tomb in central Giza (G 8990), and a number of surviving limestone statues and other objects of Mersuankh and his wife are now in the Cairo collection (e.g. JE 66618-66620, Egyptian Museum Cairo). His title here appears to be an abbreviation of another attested title found within his mastaba, ‘overseer of the young men of the estate of the companion Ra-wer’ (Hassan 1932). The object was formerly part of the Albert Gautier collection (Reeves 1979). Further Bibliography: N. Reeves, 1979. ‘A New Statue Fragment for Mersuankh’, Göttinger Miszellen Issue 35, p. 47- 49.
Condition: Good. Lower and rear surfaces abraded, back of plinth chipped.
Acquisition name: Purchased through: Dr Carl Nicholas Reeves
